Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of cult attendant with erect phallus, carrying a bag or purse. Head and shoulders missing. Mould-made and hollow with vent at back. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that was operational from the 3rd to the 2nd century BC. ‘Processional’ cult attendant, leaning to the left as if carrying something heavy, possibly Theophoros (god bearer). Amphora in the background may represent a Ptolemaic Egyptian AE1 amphora (3rd to 2nd century BC). 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, no. 3151), but also Roman examples have been found (Bailey 2008, no. 3152 and 3153; Dunand 1990; 189, no. 512, from 'Antinoe', dated 2nd to 3rd century AD) Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.535) (Phase 1)
